metadata.case_name: Petition under Article 32 by Mr. G

facts.text: This is a petition under article 32 of Constitution and raises the same question on the merits as in the connected summons case in which we have just delivered judgment. The facts will be found there.

In the present matter... number question arises about the breach of a fundamental right. But as a matter touching the jurisdiction of the Bar Council Tribunal and that of the Bombay High Court was argued.

At a very early stage [Mr. G] applied to the Registrar and also to the Prothonotary for a copy of the order of the Chief Justice constituting the Tribunal. He was told by the Prothonotary that the order was oral.
Mr. G put in two written statements before the Tribunal and did not challenge this statement of fact in either. He contented himself with saying that the order was not judicial and so was not valid.
He took up the same attitude in the High Court.

The learned Judges [High Court] said - The record clearly shows that when it came to the notice of this Court it was decided to refer this case to the Bar Council under section 10(2) and accordingly a Tribunal was appointed under section 11(1) by the learned Chief Justice of this Court.
In his petition to this Court he did not challenge this statement of fact but again confined his attack to the question of the validity of the order.

The letter No. G-1003 dated 29th April, 1953, of the Prothonotary to the Registrar and the letter No. E. 41-09/53 dated the 1st May, 1953, of the Registrar to the Bar Council office copies of which were retained on the files are a sufficient record of the making of the order.
Mr. G was supplied with copies of these letters and so was aware of the fact that orders had been issued.

We have seen the originals of the High Courts office files and find that the names of the three members of the Tribunal are in the Chief Justices handwriting with his initials underneath. That is an additional record of the making of the order.
There was no complaint to the High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the proceedings before the Tribunal were ultra vires because there was no proper order of appointment, specifically whether an oral order by the Chief Justice is sufficient under sections 10(2) and 11 of the Bar Councils Act.
Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to refer the matter to the Tribunal in the absence of a complaint.

petitioner_arguments.text: The proceedings before the Tribunal were ultra vires because there was no proper order of appointment. The order was oral and not judicial, so not valid.
There was no complaint to the High Court and so it had no jurisdiction to refer the matter to the Tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: It is evident from all this that the fact that an oral order was made was not challenged. We cannot allow Mr. G to go behind that.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fact of oral order not challenged by petitioner in Tribunal, High Court, or Supreme Court.

court_reasoning.text: Bar Councils Act does not lay down any procedure. All it says is - Section 10(2) the High Court may of its own motion so refer any case... and section 11(2) says - The Tribunal shall consist of not less than three members... appointed... by the Chief Justice. We agree it is necessary that there should be some record of the order on the files but, in our opinion, the order itself need not be a written one it can be an oral order given to a proper officer of the Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Oral order sufficient if recorded on files.

court_reasoning.text: In the present case, the letter No. G-1003 dated 29th April, 1953... and the letter No. E. 41-09/53 dated the 1st May, 1953... are a sufficient record... Mr. G was supplied with copies... As a matter of fact, we have seen the originals... names... in the Chief Justices handwriting with his initials underneath.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Letters and Chief Justice's handwriting constitute sufficient record.

court_reasoning.text: We hold that an order recorded in the manner set out above is sufficient for the purposes of section 10(2) and 11(2) of the Bar Councils Act and hold that the Tribunal was validly appointed.
This ignores the fact that the High Court can refer a matter of this kind of its own motion under section 10(2) of the Bar Councils Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No complaint required; High Court suo motu power.

holdings.text: An order appointing the Tribunal need not be written; an oral order given to a proper officer, recorded on files via letters and Chief Justice's handwriting, is sufficient under sections 10(2) and 11(2) of the Bar Councils Act.
High Court has jurisdiction to refer matter to Tribunal on its own motion under section 10(2) even without a complaint.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of the petition alleging breach of fundamental right

statutes_cited.name: Bar Councils Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs High Court's power to refer cases suo motu and Chief Justice's appointment of Tribunal; oral order with record held sufficient

outcome.summary: The Court rejected challenges to the jurisdiction of the Bar Council Tribunal and Bombay High Court, holding the oral appointment order validly recorded and High Court empowered to act suo motu under section 10(2) Bar Councils Act. Merits dealt with in connected case.

key_quotes.text: We hold that an order recorded in the manner set out above is sufficient for the purposes of section 10(2) and 11(2) of the Bar Councils Act and hold that the Tribunal was validly appointed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of oral order

key_quotes.text: The High Court can refer a matter of this kind of its own motion under section 10(2) of the Bar Councils Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies High Court's suo motu jurisdiction
